sapia:sect-desc.p: The prerequisite to the other tutorials is to build the Corus sample applications from the source. This sections shows you how.

sapia:sect2.title: Checkout and Build
sapia:sect2.p: The Corus source code is structured according to the following diagram:
The source code can be checked out anonymously from the Gitub repository Github repository, and built with Maven.
If you browse the Subversion repository, you'll see that there are many Sapia projects that are kept following Subversion's conventions, and Corus is one of them:

ul.li: trunk: where the main branches of the different projects is kept (each Sapia project has its own subfolder under the trunk).
tags: where the releases (generated by the Maven release plugin) are created.
branches: where the development branches are created (each Sapia project has its own subfolder under “branches”).

sapia:sect2.p: The folders under “tags” are created by the Maven release plugin, which uses a combination of the artifact ID and version for the subfolder's name. Each such subfolder therefore corresponds to a specific project release.
For the purpose of the tutorials, you should checkout Corus from under the "tags" folder, picking the Corus release that corresponds to the one you've installed on your computer.

Before building, it is important to note that Corus depends on other Sapia projects. We initially started using the Java.net repository to deploy the Sapia artifacts, but have switched to having our own since. In any case, make sure that you have both configured in your Maven settings (settings.xml) - for “normal” dependencies as well as for plugins. Here's an example:
To build, just cd into the directory where you've done the checkout, and type: mvn install.
sapia:sect2.sapia:note: The Corus server's distributions (which come in the form of zip and tar archives) are generated under the modules/server/target directory (more precisely, under the “target” directory of the server module).

sapia:sect2.title: The Sample Applications
sapia:sect2.p: In the diagram below, we're showing that there are two applications under the "samples" folder:

ul.li: corus_sample_grails_app is a very limited web application built with Grails.
corus_sample_jetty is an embedded Jetty server packaged as a standalone Java application into which the above Grails app is deployed.

sapia:sect2.p: It is that Jetty server that we'll deploy into Corus in the course of the other tutorials. When the time comes, you'll just need to cd under the corus_sample_jetty folder and start the Corus CLI from there.

sapia:sect2.title: Next
sapia:sect2.p: Now that you've built Corus and the need sample apps, it's time to move on to the next tutorial.
